revision.text:
The '''Large Underground Xenon experiment''' ('''LUX''') aims to directly detect [[weakly interacting massive particle]] (WIMP) [[dark matter]] interactions with ordinary matter on Earth. Despite the wealth of (gravitational) evidence supporting the existence of non-[[baryonic]] dark matter in the Universe,<ref>{{cite journal|last=Beringer|first=J.|display-authors=etal |title=2012 Review of Particle Physics|journal=Phys. Rev. D|year=2012|volume=86|issue=010001|doi=10.1103/PhysRevD.86.010001|url=http://pdg.lbl.gov/2013/reviews/rpp2012-rev-dark-matter.pdf|bibcode = 2012PhRvD..86a0001B }}</ref> dark matter particles in our galaxy have never been directly detected in an experiment. LUX utilizes a 370 kg liquid [[xenon]] detection mass in a [[time-projection chamber]] (TPC) to identify individual particle interactions, searching for faint dark matter interactions with unprecedented sensitivity.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Akerib|first=D.|display-authors=etal |title=The Large Underground Xenon (LUX) experiment|journal=Nuclear Instruments and Methods in Physics Research A|date=March 2013|volume=704|pages=111–126|doi=10.1016/j.nima.2012.11.135|arxiv = 1211.3788 |bibcode = 2013NIMPA.704..111A }}</ref>
The LUX experiment, which cost approximately $10 million to build,<ref>[http://www.nature.com/news/dark-matter-hunt-gets-deep-1.12455 Reich, E. Dark-matter hunt gets deep ''Nature'' 21 Feb 2013]</ref> is located {{convert|4950|ft|m|abbr=on|order=flip}} underground at the [[Sanford Underground Laboratory]] (SURF, formerly the Deep Underground Science and Engineering Laboratory, or DUSEL) in the [[Homestake Mine (South Dakota)]] in [[Lead, South Dakota]]. The detector is located in the Davis campus, former site of the Nobel Prize-winning [[Homestake experiment|Homestake neutrino experiment]] led by [[Raymond Davis, Jr.|Raymond Davis]]. It is operated underground to reduce the background noise signal caused by high-energy [[cosmic rays]] at the Earth's surface.
[[File:Large Underground Xenon detector inside watertank.jpg|thumb|alt=The Large Underground Xenon experiment installed {{convert|4850|ft|m|abbr=on|order=flip}} underground inside the water tank shield.|The Large Underground Xenon experiment installed {{convert|4850|ft|m|abbr=on|order=flip}} underground inside a {{convert|70000|USgal|m3|abbr=on|order=flip}} water tank shield. The experiment is a 370 kg liquid xenon [[time projection chamber]] that aims to detect the faint interactions between [[Weakly interacting massive particles|WIMP]] dark matter and ordinary matter.]]
== Detector principle ==
The detector is isolated from background particles by a surrounding water tank and the earth above. This shielding reduces cosmic rays and radiation interacting with the xenon.
Interactions in liquid xenon generate 175 nm ultraviolet [[photons]] and electrons. The photons are immediately detected by two arrays of 61 [[photomultiplier tubes]] at the top and bottom of the detector. These prompt photons are the S1 signal. Electrons generated by the particle interactions drift upwards towards the xenon gas by an electric field. The electrons are pulled in the gas at the surface by a stronger electric field, and produce [[electroluminescence]] photons detected as the S2 signal. The S1 and subsequent S2 signal constitute a particle interaction in the liquid xenon.
The detector is a [[time-projection chamber]] (TPC), using the time between S1 and S2 signals to find the interaction depth since electrons move at constant velocity in the liquid (around 1–2 km/s, depending on the electric field). The x-y coordinate of the event is inferred from electroluminescence photons at the top array by statistical methods ([[Monte Carlo method|Monte Carlo]] and [[maximum likelihood estimation]]) to a resolution under 1 cm.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Akerib|display-authors=etal |title=Technical results from the surface run of the LUX dark matter experiment|journal=Astroparticle Physics|date=May 2013|volume=45|pages=34–43|doi=10.1016/j.astropartphys.2013.02.001|bibcode = 2013APh....45...34A |arxiv=1210.4569}}</ref>
[[File:LUXEvent.pdf|thumb|alt=A particle interaction in the LUX detector|Particle interactions inside the LUX detector produce photons and electrons. The photons (γ), moving at the speed of light, are quickly detected by the photomultiplier tubes. This photon signal is called S1. An electric field in the liquid xenon drifts the electrons towards the liquid surface. A much higher electric field above the liquid surface pulls the electrons out of the liquid and into the gas, where they produce [[electroluminescence]] photons (in the same way that neon sign produces light). The electroluminescence photons are detected by the photomultiplier tubes as the S2 signal. A single particle interaction in the liquid xenon can be identified by the pair of an S1 and an S2 signal.]]<!--(WORKING ON THIS...) The LUX detector is a cylindrical volume filled with liquid and gas xenon. Two arrays of 61 photomultiplier tubes (PMTs) each are located at the top and bottom of the cylindrical volume. The photomultiplier tubes detect the light emitted by particle interactions in the liquid xenon. Two wire-strung grids placed at the bottom and top of the liquid surface provide an electric field-->
[[File:Large Underground Xenon detector diagram.png|thumb|alt=Schematic of the Large Underground Xenon detector|Schematic of the Large Underground Xenon (LUX) detector. The detector consists of an inner [[cryostat]] filled with 370 kg of liquid xenon (300 kg in the inner region, called the "active volume") cooled to −100 °C. 122 [[photomultiplier tubes]] detect light generated inside the detector. The LUX detector has an outer cryostat that provides vacuum insulation. An 8-meter-diameter by 6-meter-high water tank shields the detector from external radiation, such as [[gamma ray]]s and [[neutrons]]. ]] <!-- WILL EDIT THIS SOON Liquid xenon both [[scintillation (physics)|scintillates]] and becomes ionized when hit by particles like photons, neutrons, and potentially WIMP dark matter. The ratio of scintillation over ionization energy caused by the collision provides a way of identifying the interacting particle. WIMPs ([[Weakly Interacting Massive Particle]]s), the leading theoretical dark matter candidate, could be identified in this way. --> <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Large Underground Xenon PMT Hamamatsu R8778.jpg|thumb|alt=One of the photomultiplier tubes used in the Large Underground Xenon experiment.| One of the 122 [[photomultiplier tubes]] (PMTs) used for signal detection in the LUX experiment. The PMTs are model R8778 by [[Hamamatsu Photonics]]. The PMTs have low levels of radioactive impurities, which makes them suitable for a low radioactive background experiment such as LUX. The PMTs are sensitive to single [[photon]]s and can detect the 175 nm ultraviolet light emitted in liquid xenon particle interactions with an efficiency of about 30%.]] -->
== Finding dark matter == WIMPs would be expected to interact exclusively with the liquid xenon nuclei, resulting in nuclear recoils that would appear very similar to neutron collisions. In order to single out WIMP interactions, neutron events must be minimized, through shielding and ultra-quiet building materials.
In order to discern WIMPs from neutrons, the number of single interactions must be compared to multiple events. Since WIMPs are expected to be so weakly interacting, most would pass through the detector unnoticed. Any WIMPs that interact will have negligible chance of repeated interaction. Neutrons, on the other hand, have a reasonably large chance of multiple collisions within the target volume, the frequency of which can be accurately predicted. Using this knowledge, if the ratio of single interactions to multiple interactions exceeds a certain value, the detection of dark matter may be reliably inferred.
== Collaboration == The "XENON Collaboration" is composed of over 100 scientists and engineers across 18 institutions in the US, Europe, and Middle East. LUX is composed of the majority of the US groups that collaborated in the [[XENON Dark Matter Search Experiment#XENON10|XENON10]] experiment, most of the groups in the [[ZEPLIN-III|ZEPLIN III]] experiment, the majority of the US component of the ZEPLIN II experiment, and groups involved in low-background rare event searches such as [[Super-Kamiokande|Super Kamiokande]], [[Sudbury Neutrino Observatory|SNO]], [[IceCube]], [[Kamland]], [[Enriched Xenon Observatory|EXO]] and [[Double Chooz]].
The LUX experiment's co-spokespersons are [[Richard Gaitskell]] from [[Brown University]] (acting as co-spokesperson since 2007) and Daniel McKinsey from [[Yale University]] (acting as co-spokesperson since 2012). Tom Shutt from [[Case Western Reserve University]] was LUX co-spokesperson between 2007-2012.
== Status == Detector assembly began in late 2009. The LUX detector was commissioned overground at SURF for a six-month run. The assembled detector was transported underground from the surface laboratory in a two-day operation in the summer of 2012 and began data taking April 2013, presenting initial results Fall 2013. LUX plans to operate into 2015 and perform a blinded analysis of 300 live days. The next-generation 7-ton LUX-ZEPLIN has been approved,<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://physicsworld.com/cws/article/news/2014/jul/15/dark-matter-searches-get-us-government-approval|title = Dark-matter searches get US government approval|date = July 15, 2014|work = Physics World|accessdate = }}</ref> expected to begin in 2020.<ref name=Hamish2016>{{cite web|title=World's most sensitive dark-matter search comes up empty handed|url=http://physicsworld.com/cws/article/news/2016/jul/22/worlds-most-sensitive-dark-matter-search-comes-up-empty-handed|publisher=physicsworld.com (IOP)|work=Hamish Johnston|date=22 July 2016|accessdate=24 July 2016}}</ref>
== Results == <!-- Deleted image removed: [[file: LUX IDM2016 p50 CR.png|thumb|Results from final run (2014-16): upper boundary for cross-section]] --> Initial unblinded data taken April to August 2013 were announced on October 30, 2013. In an 85 live-day run with 118 kg fiducial volume, LUX obtained 160 events passing the data analysis selection criteria, all consistent with electron recoil backgrounds. A [[profile likelihood]] statistical approach shows this result is consistent with the background-only hypothesis (no WIMP interactions) with a [[p-value]] of 0.35. This is the most sensitive dark matter direct detection result in the world, and rules out low-mass WIMP signal hints such as from [[CoGeNT]] and [[Cryogenic Dark Matter Search|CDMS-II]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Akerib|first=D.|title=First results from the LUX dark matter experiment at the Sanford Underground Research Facility|url=http://luxdarkmatter.org/papers/LUX_First_Results_2013.pdf|accessdate=30 October 2013}}</ref><ref>[http://www.foxnews.com/science/2013/10/30/dark-matter-search-comes-up-empty/ Dark Matter Search Comes Up Empty] Fox News, 2013 October 30</ref> These results have struck out some of the theories about WIMPs, which allows researchers to focus on fewer leads.<ref>[https://theconversation.com/dark-matter-experiment-finds-nothing-makes-news-19707 Dark matter experiment finds nothing, makes news] The Conversation, 01 November 2013</ref>
In the final run from October 2014 to May 2016, at four times its original design sensitivity with 368 kg of liquid xenon, LUX has seen no signs of dark matter candidate—WIMPs.<ref name=Hamish2016 />
==References==
{{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://luxdarkmatter.org LUX Dark Matter webpage] * [http://particleastro.brown.edu/articles/Brown_Daily_Herald_20080204_Prof_Shedding_Light_on_Dark_Matter.pdf Brown University article]
{{Dark matter}}

[[Category:Experiments for dark matter search]]

[[Image:Lemon Battery With LED V2.svg|thumb|right|Diagram showing three lemon cells wired together so that they energize the red light emitting diode (LED) at the top. Each individual lemon has a zinc electrode and a copper electrode inserted into it; the zinc is colored gray in the diagram. The slender lines drawn between the electrodes and the LED represent the wires.|alt=A drawing showing three lemons and a glowing red object (the LED). The LED has two lines coming out of its bottom to represent its electrical leads. Each lemon has two metal pieces stuck into it; the metals are colored differently. There are thin black lines, representing wires, connecting the metal pieces stuck into each lemon and the leads of the LED.]] A '''lemon battery''' is a simple [[Electrochemical cell|battery]] often made for the purpose of education. Typically, a piece of [[zinc]] metal (such as a [[galvanized]] nail) and a piece of [[copper]] (such as a penny) are inserted into a lemon and connected by wires. Power generated by reaction of the metals is used to power a small device such as a [[light emitting diode]] (LED).
The lemon battery is similar to the [[Voltaic pile|first electrical battery]] invented in 1800 by [[Alessandro Volta]], who used [[brine]] (salt water) instead of lemon juice.<ref name=Decker /> The lemon battery illustrates the type of [[chemical reaction]] ([[redox|oxidation-reduction]]) that occurs in batteries.<ref name=Snyder /><ref name=Oon /><ref name=Goodisman /> The zinc and copper are called the [[electrode]]s, and the juice inside the lemon is called the [[electrolyte]]. There are many variations of the lemon cell that use different fruits (or liquids) as electrolytes and metals other than zinc and copper as electrodes.
==Use in school projects== There are numerous sets of instructions for making lemon batteries and for obtaining components such as [[light-emitting diode|light-emitting diodes]] (LEDs), electrical meters ([[multimeter]]s), and zinc-coated ([[galvanized]]) nails and screws.<ref name=HILA /><ref name=How /> Commercial "potato clock" science kits include electrodes and a low-voltage digital clock. After one cell is assembled, a [[multimeter]] can be used to measure the [[voltage]] or the [[electric current]] from the voltaic cell; a typical voltage is 0.9 V with lemons. Currents are more variable, but range up to about 1 mA (the larger the electrode surfaces, the bigger the current). For a more visible effect, lemon cells can be connected in [[series and parallel circuits|series]] to power an LED (see illustration) or other devices. The series connection increases the voltage available to devices. Swartling and Morgan have published a list of low-voltage devices along with the corresponding number of lemon cells that were needed to power them; they included LEDs, piezeoelectric buzzers, and small digital clocks. With the zinc/copper electrodes, at least two lemon cells were needed for any of these devices.<ref name=Swartling /> Substituting a magnesium electrode for the zinc electrode makes a cell with a larger voltage (1.5−1.6 V), and a single magnesium/copper cell will power some devices.<ref name=Swartling /> Note that incandescent light bulbs from flashlights are not used because the lemon battery is not designed to produce enough electric current to light them. By multiplying the average current of a lemon (0.001A/ 1mA) by the average (lowest) voltage (potential difference) of a lemon (0.7V) we can conclude that it would take more than 6 million lemons to give us the power of an average 4320W car battery.
==={{Anchor|Variations}}Variations=== [[Image:Potato-Battery-5495.jpg|thumb|right|Potato battery with zinc (left) and copper electrodes. The zinc electrode is a [[galvanization|galvanized]] machine screw. The copper electrode is a wire. Note the labels − and + marked on the potato indicating that the copper electrode is the positive terminal of the battery. A short screw and nut connect the electrodes to the copper wires that have black and red insulating plastic coatings. |alt=Photograph of a potato. A copper wire is stuck into the potato, and an insulated lead wire is connected to the top of it using a nut and screw. A galvanized machine screw is also suck into the face. There is a nut that is next to the screw head; the second lead wire is squashed between the head and the nut. A "+" symbol is marked on the potato's skin near the copper wire that is stuck into it.]] Many fruits and liquids can be used for the acidic electrolyte. Fruit is convenient, because it provides both the electrolyte and a simple way to support the electrodes. The acid involved in citrus fruits (lemons, oranges, grapefruits, etc.) is [[citric acid]]. The acidity, which is indicated by the measured [[pH]], varies substantially.
[[Potato]]es have [[phosphoric acid]] and work well; they are the basis for commercial "potato clock" kits.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.unit5.org/christjs/Potato%20Battery.htm |title=Potato Battery |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090415133756/http://www.unit5.org/christjs/Potato%20Battery.htm |archivedate=April 15, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=Potato Science and Technology |first1=G. |last1=Lisinska |first2=W. |last2=Leszczynski |publisher=Springer |year=1989 |isbn=9781851663071 |page=286 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WYT1S7qhn4sC&pg=PA286}}</ref> Potato batteries with [[LED]] lighting have been proposed for use in poor countries or by off-grid populations. International research begun in 2010 showed that boiling potatoes for eight minutes improves their electrical output, as does placing slices of potatoes between multiple copper and zinc plates. Boiled and chopped [[Cooking plantain|plantain pith]] (stem) is also suitable, according to Sri Lankan researchers.<ref>{{Cite web | last = Kalan | first = Jonathan | title = Potato power: the spuds that could light the world | work = BBC - Future - Technology | accessdate = 2014-01-24 | url = http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20131112-potato-power-to-light-the-world }}</ref>
Instead of fruit, liquids in various containers can be used. Household vinegar ([[acetic acid]]) works well.<ref name=Heeling /> [[Sauerkraut]] ([[lactic acid]]) was featured in one episode of the US television program ''[[Head Rush (TV series)|Head Rush]]'' (an offshoot of the ''[[MythBusters]]'' program). The sauerkraut had been canned, and became the electrolyte while the can itself was one of the electrodes.<ref>{{cite video |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KZ9KmHWKobY |title=Head Rush - Sauerkraut Clock |publisher=The Discovery Channel}} Sauerkraut is quite acidic due to the lactic acid produced during fermentation. The sauerkraut clock powers a digital thermometer in this video.</ref>
Zinc and copper electrodes are reasonably safe and easy to obtain. Other metals such as lead, iron, magnesium, etc., can be studied as well; they yield different voltages than the zinc/copper pair. In particular, magnesium/copper cells can generate voltages as large as 1.6 V in lemon cells. This voltage is larger than obtainable using zinc/copper cells. It is comparable to that of standard household batteries (1.5 V), which is useful in powering devices with a single cell instead of using cells in series.<ref name=Swartling />
===Learning outcomes=== For the youngest pupils, about ages 5–9, the educational goal is utilitarian:<ref name=Abraham /> batteries are devices that can power other devices, so long as they are connected by a conductive material. Batteries are components in electrical circuits; hooking a single wire between a battery and a light bulb will not power the bulb.
For children in the age range 10−13, batteries are used to illustrate the connection between chemistry and electricity as well as to deepen the circuit concept for electricity. The fact that different chemical elements such as copper and zinc are used can be placed in the larger context that the elements do not disappear or break down when they undergo chemical reactions.
For older pupils and for college students, batteries serve to illustrate the principles of oxidation-reduction reactions.<ref name=Abraham /><ref name=Schmidt /> Students can discover that two identical electrodes yield no voltage, and that different pairs of metals (beyond copper and zinc) yield different voltages. The voltages and currents from series and parallel combinations of the batteries can be examined.<ref name=Sorey />
The current that is output by the battery through a meter will depend on the size of the electrodes, how far the electrodes are inserted into the fruit, and how close to each other the electrodes are placed; the voltage is fairly independent of these details of the electrodes.<ref name=Du />
==Chemical== [[File:ZnCuVoltaicCell.svg|thumb|Cross-section of a copper/zinc cell with a sulfuric acid electrolyte. The drawing illustrates the atomic model for the chemical reactions; lemon cells have essentially the same model. Zinc atoms enter the electrolyte as ions missing two electrons (Zn<sup>2+</sup>). Two negatively charged electrons from the dissolved zinc atom are left in the zinc metal. Two of the dissolved protons (H<sup>+</sup>) in the acidic electrolyte combine with each other and two electrons to form molecular hydrogen H<sub>2</sub>, which bubbles off of the copper electrode. The electrons lost from the copper are made up by moving two electrons from the zinc through the external wire. |alt=Cross-section drawing of a cup. The cup is mostly full, apparently with water. Two rectangular shapes indicate a copper and a zinc piece, each of which is mostly submerged in the water. The water has about a dozen symbols in various positions: Zn<sup>2+</sup>, H<sup>+</sup>, and SO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup>. There's a circle above the water with the symbol H<sub>2</sub> inside it. There's a wire connecting the zinc and copper pieces outside of the water; 2 electrons (e<sup>−</sup>) are shown along the wire with arrows pointing from the zinc to the copper.]] Most textbooks present the following model for the chemical reactions of a lemon battery.<ref name=Decker /><ref name=Oon /><ref name=Naidu /> When the cell is providing an electric current through an external circuit, the metallic zinc at the surface of the zinc electrode is dissolving into the solution. Zinc atoms dissolve into the liquid electrolyte as electrically charged [[ions]] (Zn<sup>2+</sup>), leaving 2 negatively charged [[electron]]s (e<sup>−</sup>) behind in the metal: :Zn → Zn<sup>2+</sup> + 2e<sup>−</sup> . This reaction is called [[redox|oxidation]]. While zinc is entering the electrolyte, two positively charged [[hydrogen]] ions (H<sup>+</sup>) from the electrolyte combine with two electrons at the copper electrode's surface and form an uncharged hydrogen molecule (H<sub>2</sub>): :2H<sup>+</sup>+ 2e<sup>−</sup> → H<sub>2</sub> .
This reaction is called reduction. The electrons used in the copper to form the molecules of hydrogen are transferred from the zinc through an external wire connecting between the copper and the zinc. The hydrogen molecules formed on the surface of the copper by the reduction reaction ultimately bubble away as hydrogen gas.<!--needs photo-->
==Experiment results== This model of the chemical reactions makes several predictions that were examined in experiments published by Jerry Goodisman in 2001. Goodisman notes that numerous recent authors propose chemical reactions for the lemon battery that involve dissolution of the copper electrode into the electrolyte. Goodisman excludes this reaction as being inconsistent with the experiments, and notes that the correct chemistry, which involves the evolution of hydrogen at the copper electrode but also can use silver instead of copper, has been known for many years.<ref name=Goodisman /> Most of the detailed predictions of the model apply to the battery's voltage that is measured directly by a meter; nothing else is connected to the battery. When the electrolyte was modified by adding zinc sulfate (ZnSO<sub>4</sub>), the voltage from the cell was reduced as predicted using the [[Nernst equation]] for the model. The Nernst equation essentially says how much the voltage drops as more zinc sulfate is added. The addition of copper sulfate (CuSO<sub>4</sub>) did not affect the voltage. This result is consistent with the fact that copper atoms from the electrode are not involved in the chemical reaction model for the cell.
When the battery is hooked up to an external circuit and a significant electric current is flowing, the zinc electrode loses mass, as predicted by the zinc oxidation reaction above. Similarly, hydrogen gas evolves as bubbles from the copper electrode. Finally, the voltage from the cell depended upon the acidity of the electrolyte, as measured by its pH; decreasing acidity (and increasing pH) causes the voltage to fall. This effect is also predicted by the Nernst equation; the particular acid that was used (citric, hydrochloric, sulfuric, etc.) doesn't affect the voltage except through the pH value.
The Nernst equation prediction failed for strongly acid electrolytes (pH < 3.4), when the zinc electrode dissolves into the electrolyte even when the battery is not providing any current to a circuit. The two oxidation-reduction reactions listed above only occur when electrical charge can be transported through the external circuit. The additional, open-circuit reaction can be observed by the formation of bubbles at the zinc electrode under open-circuit. This effect ultimately limited the voltage of the cells to 1.0 V near room temperature at the highest levels of acidity.
===Energy source===
The energy comes from the chemical change in the zinc when it dissolves into the acid. The energy does not come from the lemon or potato. The zinc is [[oxidized]] inside the lemon, exchanging some of its electrons with the acid in order to reach a lower energy state, and the energy released provides the power.<ref name=Goodisman />
In current practice, zinc is produced by [[electrowinning]] of [[zinc sulfate]] or pyrometallurgical reduction of zinc with carbon, which requires an energy input. The energy produced in the lemon battery comes from reversing this reaction, recovering some of the energy input during the zinc production.
===Smee cell=== From 1840 to the late 19th century, large, voltaic cells using a zinc electrode and a sulfuric acid electrolyte were widely used in the printing industry. While copper electrodes like those in lemon batteries were sometimes used, in 1840 [[wikisource:Smee, Alfred (DNB00)|Alfred Smee]] invented a refined version of this cell that used silver with a rough platinum coating instead of a copper electrode.<ref name=Magazine /><ref name=Bottone /> Hydrogen gas clinging to the surface of a silver or copper electrode reduces the electric current that can be drawn from a cell; the phenomenon is called "polarization".<ref name=Naidu /><ref name=Watt /> The roughened, "platinized" surface speeds up the bubbling of the hydrogen gas, and increases the current from the cell. Unlike the zinc electrode, the copper or platinized silver electrodes are not consumed by using the battery, and the details of this electrode do not affect the cell's voltage. The Smee cell was convenient for [[electrotyping]], which produced copper plates for letterpress printing of newspapers and books, and also statues and other metallic objects.<ref name=Bottone /><ref name=Gordon /><ref name=Hatch /><ref name=Sprague /><ref name=Scott />
The Smee cell used [[amalgamated zinc]] instead of pure zinc; the surface of amalgamated zinc has been treated with mercury.<ref name=Sprague /> Apparently amalgamated zinc was less prone to degradation by an acidic solution than is pure zinc.<ref name=Park /> Amalgamated zinc and plain zinc electrodes give essentially the same voltage when the zinc is pure.<ref name=van>The standard electrode potential is 0.76 V for both pure zinc and for amalgamated zinc. See {{cite book |last=Vanýsek |first=Petr |year=2012 |editor-last=Haynes |editor-first=William M. |chapter=Electrochemical Series |pages=5–80 |title=Handbook of Chemistry and Physics: 93rd Edition |publisher=Chemical Rubber Company |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-BzP7Rkl7WkC&pg=SA5-PA80 |isbn=9781439880494}}.</ref> With the imperfectly refined zinc in 19th century laboratories they typically gave different voltages.<ref name=Park />
==In popular culture== {{refimprove-section|date=January 2015}} <!--ADD ONLY EXAMPLES WHERE THE SUBJECT HAS A MAJOR ROLE IN THE PLOT, THEME, EPISODE ETC. ONES WITH ONLY MINOR REFERENCES CAN BE REMOVED--> *In the video game ''[[Portal 2]]'', antagonist [[GLaDOS]] was embedded into a potato-battery-run computer for a significant part of the game.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Noble|first1=Mckinley|title=Portal 2 Science Kit Has Talking, Evil Potato GLaDOS|url=http://www.techhive.com/article/246545/portal_2_science_kit_has_talking_evil_potato_glados.html|website=techhive|accessdate=30 January 2015|date=19 December 2011}}</ref> *In ''[[The Big Bang Theory]]'' Season 6 episode "The Proton Resurgence", Leonard and Sheldon's childhood hero Professor Proton (Bob Newhart) attempts to show the group a potato battery, which amazes Penny. *In the ''[[Bones (TV series)|Bones]]'' Season 6 episode "The Blackout in the Blizzard", Angela and the other "squints" build a massive potato battery array in an attempt to power a cell phone. Illustrating the pathetically low output of such a system, it is successful for only a handful of seconds while using dozens of potatoes. *In the episode "[[Lemons (Red Dwarf)|Lemons]]" of the television program ''[[Red Dwarf]]'' ([[Red Dwarf (series X)|tenth series (Series X)]]), the crew travel 4,000 miles from [[Prehistoric Britain|Britain]] to [[India]] in 23 AD in order to get lemons to build a lemon battery to power up their [[Time travel|time machine]]'s returner remote.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Keeling|first1=Robert|title=TV Review: RED DWARF X Episode 3 'Lemons'|journal=Starburst|date=19 October 2012|url=http://www.starburstmagazine.com/reviews/television-reviews/3733-tv-review-red-dwarf-x-episode-3-lemons|accessdate=30 January 2015}}</ref> *In the sixth episode of the final season of ''[[Mystery Science Theater 3000]]'', the main villain [[Pearl Forrester]] tried taking over the world using potato batteries, only for her plans to be ruined by [[Professor Bobo]]. *In ''[[NCIS (TV series)|NCIS]]'' Season 7 episode 8, "Power Down", Abby Sciuto uses lemons as a power source for her stereo when she runs out of batteries during a blackout. *In [[Terry Pratchett]] and [[Stephen Baxter (author)|Stephen Baxter]]'s [[The Long Earth (series)]] the devices used to step from one universe to another appear to be powered by potato batteries.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Adam|first1=Roberts|title=The Long Earth by Terry Pratchett and Stephen Baxter – review|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2012/jun/20/long-earth-terry-pratchett-stephen-baxter-review|website=The Guardian|accessdate=8 February 2017}}</ref> <!--ADD ONLY EXAMPLES WHERE THE SUBJECT HAS A MAJOR ROLE IN THE PLOT, THEME, EPISODE ETC. ONES WITH ONLY MINOR REFERENCES CAN BE REMOVED-->

==References== {{reflist |refs= <ref name=Abraham>{{cite journal |title=Electrochemistry for K-12: The Potato Clock and Beyond |first1=Ann |last1=Abraham |first2=Attila |last2=Palencsar |first3=Daniel |last3=Scherson |journal=The Electrochemical Society Interface |volume=15 |issue=3 |date=Fall 2006 |url=https://www.electrochem.org/dl/interface/fal/fal06/fall06_p43-46.pdf}}</ref> <ref name=Bottone>{{cite book |last=Bottone |first=Selimo Romeo |title=Galvanic batteries, their theory, construction and use, comprising primary, single and double fluid cells, secondary and gas batteries |publisher=Whittaker & Co. |year=1902 |page=88 |quote=The first real improvement over the plain zinc-copper in acid cell was due to Dr. Alfred Smee, who noticed that the hydrogen gas liberated at the negative plate was evolved from it much more readily, hence polarization took place much less rapidly if the surface of this plate were roughened instead of being quite smooth; and the means he found most efficient was that of coating the silver sheet or sheets with finely divided platinum ... |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SSQ6AQAAIAAJ&pg=PA88 }}</ref> <ref name=Decker>{{cite web|last=Decker |first=Franco |work=Electrochemistry Encyclopedia |title=Volta and the 'Pile' |date=January 2005 |publisher=Case Western Reserve University |url=http://electrochem.cwru.edu/encycl/art-v01-volta.htm |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120716205546/http://electrochem.cwru.edu/encycl/art-v01-volta.htm |archivedate=2012-07-16 |df= }} Volta used silver, not copper, in his first cells; the chemical reactions involved in zinc/copper and zinc/silver cells are the same.</ref> <ref name=Du>{{cite web |last=Du |first=James |title=Fruit/veg batteries |url=http://www.odec.ca/projects/2011/duduj2/fruit-veg-battery.html |year=2011}} A quantitative study of both the voltages and currents produced by fruit batteries; part of a larger project including "penny batteries".</ref> <ref name=Goodisman>{{cite journal |last=Goodisman |first=Jerry |title=Observations on Lemon Cells |journal=Journal of Chemical Education |year=2001 |volume=78 |pages=516–518 |issue=4 |url=http://surface.syr.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1001&context=che |doi=10.1021/ed078p516|bibcode=2001JChEd..78..516G }}</ref> <ref name=Gordon>{{cite book |title=A physical treatise on electricity and magnetism, Volume 1 |first=James Edward Henry |last=Gordon |publisher=D. Appleton and Company |year=1880 |page=207 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bBqAAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA207&lpg=PA207}}</ref> <ref name=Hatch>{{cite book |last1=Hatch |first1=Harris B. |last2=Stewart |first2=Alexander A. |title=Electrotyping and stereotyping |publisher=United Typothetae of America |location=Chicago |year=1918 |pages=2–4 |chapter=History of Electrotype Making |quote=In 1840 Smee invented a battery which made electrotyping possible commercially. ... Perhaps one of the greatest forward steps in connection with electrotyping was made when the plating dynamo was invented. The first adoption of a dynamo, in place of the Smee type of battery, was by Leslie, of New York, in 1872. |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VnQsAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA2}} Primer for apprentices in the printing industry. Good short introduction to the history of electrotyping.</ref> <ref name=Heeling>{{cite web |url=https://www.cool-solar-stuff.com/solar-diy/diy-vinegar-battery-lights-led/ |last=Heeling |first=Harmjan |title=DIY vinegar battery lights LEDs for several days |date=May 12, 2012}}</ref> <ref name=HILA>{{cite web |url=http://www.hilaroad.com/camp/projects/lemon/lemon_battery.html |title=Lemon Battery |publisher=Hila Science Camp |location=Pembroke, Ontario |accessdate=2012-10-02}} This webpage describes experiments starting with a single lemon cell that is studied with a multimeter, and then leads to a lemon battery capable of lighting an LED. Hila Science Camp has also posted a video showing how to build the battery and light an LED; see {{YouTube |id=AY9qcDCFeVI |title=Create a Lemon Battery}}.</ref> <ref name=How>{{cite web |title=Lemon Battery Project |publisher=How Things Work Science Projects |location=Burlington, Iowa |url=http://www.how-things-work-science-projects.com/lemon-battery.html#lemon_battery |accessdate=2012-10-11}} This webpage contains instructions for elementary school teachers. The project uses the voltmeter to show that the battery is working. A key element is that several pairs of electrodes are used (iron/zinc, iron/copper, as well as zinc/copper) to yield different voltages.</ref> <ref name=Magazine>{{cite journal |title=Mr. Smee's Galvanic Battery |work=The Magazine of Science and School of Arts |date=April 18, 1840 |volume=II |page=22 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=r-wTAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA22 |quote=Formerly, a galvanic battery was a stupendous, and an expensive, machine occupying a large space and costing a considerable sum to keep it in its short-lived action. Now, a far more powerful instrument may be made in a snuff box and carried in the pocket. These remarks are forced upon us by the astonishing platinum batteries of Mr. Grove, and the chemico-mechanical batteries invented by Mr. Smee ...}}</ref> <ref name=Naidu>{{cite book |title=Introduction to Electrical Engineering |first1=M. S. |last1=Naidu |first2=S. |last2=Kamakshiaih |publisher=Tata McGraw-Hill Education |year=1995 |isbn=9780074622926 |page=50 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eEOzTDHWCyYC&pg=PA50}}</ref> <ref name=Oon>{{cite book |title=Chemistry Expression: An Inquiry Approach |page=236 |last=Oon |first=Hock Leong |publisher=Panpac Education Pte Ltd. |year=2007 |isbn=978-981-271-162-5 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jd-BR-nfzIoC&pg=PA236}}</ref> <ref name=Park>{{cite book |title=The Voltaic Cell: its Construction and its Capacity |last=Park |first=Benjamin |publisher=J. Wiley |year=1893 |page=347 |quote=The singular property possessed by amalgamated zinc of not being attacked by sulphuric acid diluted with water is due to the adhesion of hydrogen on the plate in the acid solution |oclc=7399515 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_N8JAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA347&lpg=PA347}}</ref> <ref name=Schmidt>{{cite journal |title=Factors that prevent learning in electrochemistry |last1=Schmidt |first1=Hans-Jürgen |last2=Marohn |first2=Annette |last3=Harrison |first3=Allan G. |journal=Journal of Research in Science Teaching |volume=44 |year=2007 |pages=258–283 |doi=10.1002/tea.20118|bibcode=2007JRScT..44..258S }} Full text by subscription only.</ref> <ref name=Scott>{{cite book |last=Scott |first=David A. |title=Copper and bronze in art: corrosion, colorants, conservation |page=22 |publisher=Getty Publications |year=2002 |isbn=978-0-89236-638-5 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yQKuSOzkLvcC&pg=PA22 |quote=Some extremely important commissions were made in electrotypes, such as the "bronzes" that adorn the Opera, Paris, and the 320 cm high statue of Prince Albert and four accompanying figures, erected behind the Albert Hall in London as a memorial to the Great Exhibition of 1851.}}</ref> <ref name=Snyder>{{cite book |title=The Extraordinary Chemistry of Ordinary Things, with Late Nite Labs: Edition 4 |first=Carl H. |last=Snyder |publisher=John Wiley & Sons |year=2004 |isbn=9780471588399}}</ref> <ref name=Sorey>{{cite book |title=Fuel for Thought: Building Energy Awareness in Grades 9-12 |editor1-last=Metz |editor1-first=Steve |publisher=[[National Science Teachers Association|NSTA]] Press |year=2012 |isbn=9781936137206 |chapter=Juan's Dilemma: A New Twist on the Old Lemon Battery |first1=Timothy |last1=Sorey |first2=Vanessa |last2=Hunt |first3=Evguenia |last3=Balandova |first4=Bruce |last4=Palmquist |pages=91–98 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=r-2KlvlgE5QC&pg=PA95}} Guide to lemon battery experiments for science teachers, including both fabrication notes and educational outcomes.</ref> <ref name=Sprague>{{cite journal |work=The Telegraphic Journal and Electrical Review |volume=II |issue=34 |title=Electro-deposition of Metals |last=Sprague |first=J. T. |pages=237–239 |date=July 1, 1874 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aulQAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA238 |quote=The Smee cell is the cell most commonly employed because of its extreme simplicity of construction and management.}} A detailed discussion of the construction and maintenance of Smee cells, c. 1874.</ref> <ref name=Swartling>{{cite journal |title=Lemon Cells Revisited—The Lemon-Powered Calculator |first1=Daniel J. |last1=Swartling |first2=Charlotte |last2=Morgan |journal=Journal of Chemical Education |volume=75 |year=1998 |pages=181–182 |issue=2 |doi=10.1021/ed075p181 |url=http://www.wsanford.com/~wsanford/gr8ps/zz_old-files/green/wheres_the_juice/lemon_battery.pdf |accessdate=2012-10-15|bibcode=1998JChEd..75..181S }} These authors note that hydrogen evolves from the zinc electrode. As described somewhat later by Goodisman, this effect is unrelated to the evolution of hydrogen that occurs when the cell is providing electric current to an external circuit; the hydrogen associated with these currents evolves from the copper electrode.</ref> <ref name=Watt>{{cite book |title=The Chemist ; Or, Reporter of Chemical Discoveries and Improvements, Volume 1 |editor1-last=Watt |editor1-first=Charles |editor2-last=Watt |editor2-first=John |chapter=Review: Proceedings of the London Electrical Society, 1841-1842 Session |quote=Of the application of this cell a very important modification can be arranged, by converting it into an ACID ''battery'', analogous to the platinized silver of Mr. Smee. Those who are acquainted with the ingenious device of that gentleman, are aware that the characteristic of his arrangement is, that the negative plate, where hydrogen is released, shall part with this hydrogen very readily. Under ordinary circumstances, the hydrogen adheres very much to the plates of an acid battery, and throws a considerable portion of the plates out of the action, by its presence on their surfaces. To remedy this, he has, as he terms it, "platinized" the surfaces. |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lYAFAAAAQAAJ&pg=RA1-PA237 |publisher=R. Hastings |location=London |year=1840 }}</ref> |30em}}
==Further reading== *{{cite web |title=Maglab - Simple Electrical Cell Tutorial |url=https://nationalmaglab.org/education/magnet-academy/watch-play/interactive/simple-electrical-cell |publisher=US National High Magnetic Field Laboratory |accessdate=2012-11-30}} Description of an acid cell with zinc & copper electrodes, including a JAVA-based animation. The animation shows zinc dissolving into the electrolyte, electrons flowing from the zinc to the copper electrodes, and little hydrogen bubbles coming off the copper electrode. The animation also suggests that a single cell can light an LED, which is not possible for LEDs that emit visible light. *<!--The reference is included here because of the popularity of the television program.-->{{cite book |title=Mythbusters Science Fair Book |first=Samantha |last=Margles |chapter=Does a Lemon Battery Really Work? |publisher=Scholastic |year=2011 |pages=104–108 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QjJHga9HlQgC&pg=PA104 |isbn=9780545237451 |accessdate=2012-10-07}} Online preview only.
==External links== * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Z8JSERBr8jI Lemon Battery video]. Cool and fun animated video explaining in great detail how a lemon battery works from the inside. * [http://www.metacafe.com/watch/800526/orange_battery/ Orange battery video]. The orange battery powers an inexpensive digital watch. * {{YouTube |id=m64ogRLvDsI |title=Potato battery video}}. Three potato cells in series power a calculator.

revision.comment: Automated edit: fixing infobox parameter "country" (violation of [[MOS:OVERLINK]])
/* Phenomenological Hamiltonian for the j=3/2 states */
revision.text:
In semiconductors, [[valence bands]] are well characterized by 3 Luttinger parameters. At the ''Г''-point in the [[band structure]], <math>p_{3/2} </math> and <math>p_{1/2} </math> orbitals form valence bands. But spin-orbit coupling splits sixfold degeneracy into high energy 4-fold and lower energy 2-fold bands. Again 4-fold degeneracy is lifted into heavy- and light hole bands by phenomenological Hamiltonian by [[J. M. Luttinger]].
==Three valence band state== In the presence of [[spin-orbit interaction]], total angular momentum should take part in. From the three valence band, l=1 and s=1/2 state generate six state of |j,m<sub>j</sub>> as <math> |{3 \over 2}, \pm {3 \over 2} \rangle, |{3 \over 2}, \pm {1 \over 2}\rangle, |{1 \over 2}, \pm {1 \over 2}\rangle </math>
The spin-orbit interaction from the relativistic quantum mechanics, lowers the energy of ''j''=1/2 states down.
==Phenomenological Hamiltonian for the ''j''=3/2 states== Phenomenological Hamiltonian in spherical approximation is written as<ref name="Hartmut Haug, Stephan W. Koch 0">{{cite book |title=Quantum Theory of the Optical and Electronic Properties of Semiconductors |author=Hartmut Haug, Stephan W. Koch |page=46 |year=2004 |edition=4th |publisher=World Scientific}}</ref>
<math> H= {{\hbar^2} \over {2m_0}} [(\gamma _1+{{5} \over {2}} \gamma _2) \mathbf{k}^2 -2\gamma_2 (\mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{J})^2]</math>
Phenomenological Luttinger parameters <math> \gamma _i </math> are defined as
<math> \alpha = \gamma _1 + {5 \over 2} \gamma _2 </math>
and
<math> \beta = \gamma _2 </math>
If we take <math> \mathbf{k} </math> as <math> \mathbf{k}=k \hat{e}_z </math>, the Hamiltonian is diagonalized for <math>j=3/2</math> states.
<math> E = { {\hbar^2 k^2} \over {2m_0} }( \gamma _1 + {{5} \over {2}} \gamma _2 - 2 \gamma _2 m_j^2)</math>
Two degenerated resulting eigenenergies are
<math> E _{hh} = { {\hbar^2 k^2} \over {2m_0} }( \gamma _1 - 2 \gamma _2)</math> for <math> m_j = \pm {3 \over 2} </math>
<math> E _{lh} = { {\hbar^2 k^2} \over {2m_0} }( \gamma _1 + 2 \gamma _2)</math> for <math> m_j = \pm {1 \over 2} </math>
<math> E_{hh} </math> (<math> E_{lh} </math>) indicates heav-(light-) hole band energy. If we regard the electrons as nearly free electrons, the Luttinger parameters describe [[Effective mass (solid-state physics)|effective mass]] of electron in each bands.
==Measurement of Luttinger parameters== Luttinger parameter can be measured by Hot-electron luminescence experiment.
==Example: GaAs== <math> \epsilon _{h,l} = - {{1} \over {2}} \gamma _{1} k^{2} \pm [ {\gamma_{2}}^{2} k^{4} + 3 ({\gamma _{3}}^{2} - {\gamma _{2}}^{2} ) \times ( {k_{x}}^{2} {k_{z}}^{2} + {k_{x}}^{2} {k_{y}}^{2} + {k_{y}}^{2}{k_{z}}^{2})]^{1/2}</math>
==References== {{reflist}}
==See also== *{{cite book | url=http://www.worldscientific.com/worldscibooks/10.1142/8875 | title=Luttinger Model: The First 50 Years and Some New Directions | publisher=World Scientific | year=2013 | last1 = Mastropietro | first1 = Vieri | last2 = Mattis | first2 = Daniel C. | isbn = 978-981-4520-71-3}} * J. M. Luttinger, Physical Review, Vol. '''102''', 1030 (1956). [http://prola.aps.org/abstract/PR/v102/i4/p1030_1 APS] * A. Baldereschi and N.O. Lipari, Physical Review B., Vol. '''8''', pp. 2675 (1973). [http://prb.aps.org/abstract/PRB/v8/i6/p2697_1 APS] * A. Baldereschi and N.O. Lipari, Physical Review B., Vol. '''9''', pp. 1525 (1974). [http://prb.aps.org/abstract/PRB/v9/i4/p1525_1 APS]
[[Category:Semiconductors]]

'''Neodymium-doped yttrium lithium fluoride''' ('''Nd:YLF''') is a [[Active laser medium|lasing medium]] for [[arclamp|arc lamp]]-[[laser pumping|pumped]] and [[diode laser|diode-pumped]] [[solid-state laser]]s. The [[yttrium lithium fluoride|YLF]] crystal (LiYF<sub>4</sub>) is naturally [[birefringence|birefringent]], and commonly used laser transitions occur at 1047 nm and 1053 nm.<ref>[Thomas M. Pollak, W. F. Wing, Robert J. Grasso, E. P. Chicklis, and Hans P. Jenssen. "CW laser operation of Nd:YLF." IEEE J. Quant. Electron., 18, 159-163 (1982)]</ref>
It is used in [[Q-switching|Q-switched]] systems in part due to its relatively long fluorescence lifetime. As with [[Nd:YAG laser]]s, [[harmonic generation]] is frequently employed with Q-switched Nd:YLF to produce shorter wavelengths. A common application of frequency-doubled Nd:YLF pulses is to pump ultrafast [[Ti-sapphire laser#Chirped-pulse amplifiers|Ti:Sapphire chirped-pulse amplifiers]].
Neodymium-doped YLF can provide higher pulse energies than Nd:YAG for repetition rates of a few kHz or less. Compared to Nd:YAG, the Nd:YLF crystal is very [[brittle]] and fractures easily. It is also slightly water-[[solubility|soluble]] — a YLF laser rod may very slowly dissolve in cooling water which surrounds it.[http://www.leelaser.com/pdf/Nd-YLF%20vs%20Nd-YAG.pdf]
== See also == *[[Neodymium doped yttrium orthovanadate|Neodymium doped yttrium orthovanadate (Nd:YVO<sub>4</sub>)]] *[[Nd:YAG laser|Neodymium doped yttrium aluminum garnet (Nd:YAG) laser]]
==References== {{Reflist}} {{neodymium compounds}} {{yttrium compounds}} {{lithium compounds}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2017}} {{Primary sources|date=December 2016}} [[File:Orthorhombic bulk black phosphorus.png|thumb|Bulk black phosphorus consists of multiple phosphorene sheets]] '''Phosphorene''' is a [[2D materials|two-dimensional material]] and [[Allotropes of phosphorus|allotrope]] of [[phosphorus]]. Phosphorene can be viewed as a single layer of [[black phosphorus]], much in the same way that [[graphene]] is a single layer of [[graphite]]. Phosphorene is predicted to be a strong competitor to graphene because, in contrast to graphene, phosphorene has a [[band gap]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Five reasons phosphorene may be a new wonder material – MagLab|url = https://nationalmaglab.org/news-events/feature-stories/phosphorene-wonder-material|website = nationalmaglab.org|date = 28 July 2015 |author=Roberts, Kristin}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Carvalho|first=Alexandra|last2=Wang|first2=Min|last3=Zhu|first3=Xi|last4=Rodin|first4=Aleksandr S.|last5=Su|first5=Haibin|last6=Castro Neto|first6=Antonio H.|date=2016|title=Phosphorene: from theory to applications|journal=Nature Reviews Materials|volume=1|issue=11|doi=10.1038/natrevmats.2016.61|pmid=|pages=16061|bibcode=2016NatRM...116061C}}</ref> Phosphorene was first isolated in 2014 by mechanical exfoliation.<ref name=":-1">{{Cite journal|title = Black Phosphorus Field Effect Transistors| journal = Nature Nanotechnology|date = 2014|pages = 372–377|volume = 9| issue = 5|doi = 10.1038/nnano.2014.35|first = Likai|last = Li|first2 = Yijun|last2 = Yu|first3 = Guo|last3 = Jun Ye|first4 = Qingqin|last4 = Ge|first5 = Xuedong|last5 = Ou|first6 = Hua|last6 = Wu|first7 = Yuanbo|last7 = Zhang|pmid=24584274| bibcode = 2014NatNa...9..372L|arxiv = 1401.4117}}</ref><ref name=":-2">{{Cite journal|title = Electric Field Effect in Ultrathin Black Phosphorus| journal = Applied Physics Letters|date = 2014|pages = 103106 |volume = 104| issue = 10| doi = 10.1063/1.4868132|first = Steven P.|last = Koenig|first2 = Rostislav A.|last2 = Doganov|first3 = Henrrik|last3 = Schmidt|first4 = Antonio H.|last4 = Castro Neto|first5 = Barbaros|last5 = Ozyilmaz| bibcode = 2014ApPhL.104j3106K|arxiv = 1402.5718}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|title = Phosphorene: An Unexplored 2D Semiconductor with a High Hole Mobility|journal = ACS Nano|date = 2014|pages = 4033–4041|volume = 8|issue = 4|doi = 10.1021/nn501226z|pmid = 24655084|first = Han|last = Liu|first2 = Adam T.|last2 = Neal|first3 = Zhen|last3 = Zhu|first4 = Zhe|last4 = Luo|first5 = Xianfan|last5 = Xu|first6 = David|last6 = Tománek|first7 = Peide D.|last7 = Ye|arxiv = 1401.4133}}</ref>
== History == In the 1960s [[black phosphorus]], a layered [[semiconductor|semiconducting]] allotrope of phosphorus, was synthesized, which exhibited high [[carrier mobility]].<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Electrical and Optical Properties of Crystalline Black Phosphorus|journal = Journal of Applied Physics|date = 1963|pages = 1853–1860|volume = 34|issue = 7|doi = 10.1063/1.1729699|first = Douglas|last = Warschauer|bibcode = 1963JAP....34.1853W}}</ref> In 2014, several groups<ref name=":-1" /><ref name=":-2" /><ref name=":0" /> introduced single-layer phosphorene, a monolayer of black phosphorus. It attracted renewed attention<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Isolation and characterization of few-layer black phosphorus|journal = 2D Materials|date = 2014|volume = 1|issue = 2|pages = 025001|doi = 10.1088/2053-1583/1/2/025001|first = Andres|last = Castellanos-Gomez|first2 = Leonardo|last2 = Vicarelli|first3 = Elsa|last3 = Prada|first4 = Joshua O|last4 = Island|first5 = K L|last5 = Narasimha-Acharya|first6 = Sofya I|last6 = Blanter|first7 = Dirk J|last7 = Groenendijk|first8 = Michele|last8 = Buscema|first9 = Gary A|last9 = Steele|bibcode = 2014TDM.....1b5001C|arxiv = 1403.0499|hdl = 10486/669327}}</ref> because of its potential in [[optoelectronics]] and electronics due to its [[band gap]], which can be tuned via modifying its thickness, anisotropic photoelectronic properties and high carrier mobility.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite journal|title = Rediscovering black phosphorus as an anisotropic layered material for optoelectronics and electronics|journal = Nature Communications|volume = 5|doi = 10.1038/ncomms5458|first = Fengnian|last = Xia|first2 = Han|last2 = Wang|first3 = Yichen|last3 = Jia|year = 2014|pmid=25041752|page=4458|bibcode = 2014NatCo...5E4458X|arxiv = 1402.0270}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title = Two-dimensional crystals: Phosphorus joins the family|journal = Nature Nanotechnology|pages = 330–331|volume = 9|issue = 5|doi = 10.1038/nnano.2014.85|pmid = 24801536|first = Hugh O. H.|last = Churchill|first2 = Pablo|last2 = Jarillo-Herrero|year = 2014|bibcode = 2014NatNa...9..330C|hdl = 1721.1/91500}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title = Electric field effect in ultrathin black phosphorus|journal = Applied Physics Letters|date = 2014|pages = 103106|volume = 104|issue = 10|doi = 10.1063/1.4868132|first = Steven P.|last = Koenig|first2 = Rostislav A.|last2 = Doganov|first3 = Hennrik|last3 = Schmidt|first4 = A. H. Castro|last4 = Neto|first5 = Barbaros|last5 = Özyilmaz|bibcode = 2014ApPhL.104j3106K|arxiv = 1402.5718}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title = Strain-Induced Gap Modification in Black Phosphorus|journal = Physical Review Letters|date = 2014|pages = 176801|volume = 112|issue = 17|doi = 10.1103/PhysRevLett.112.176801|pmid = 24836264|first = A. S.|last = Rodin|first2 = A.|last2 = Carvalho|first3 = A. H.|last3 = Castro Neto|bibcode = 2014PhRvL.112q6801R|arxiv = 1401.1801}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title = Fast and Broadband Photoresponse of Few-Layer Black Phosphorus Field-Effect Transistors|journal = Nano Letters|date = 2014|pages = 3347–3352|volume = 14|issue = 6|doi = 10.1021/nl5008085|pmid = 24821381|first = Michele|last = Buscema|first2 = Dirk J.|last2 = Groenendijk|first3 = Sofya I.|last3 = Blanter|first4 = Gary A.|last4 = Steele|first5 = Herre S. J.|last5 = van der Zant|first6 = Andres|last6 = Castellanos-Gomez|bibcode = 2014NanoL..14.3347B|arxiv = 1403.0565}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title = High-mobility transport anisotropy and linear dichroism in few-layer black phosphorus|journal = Nature Communications|date = 2014|pmc = 4109013|pmid = 25042376|volume = 5|pages = 4475|doi = 10.1038/ncomms5475|first = Jingsi|last = Qiao|first2 = Xianghua|last2 = Kong|first3 = Zhi-Xin|last3 = Hu|first4 = Feng|last4 = Yang|first5 = Wei|last5 = Ji|bibcode = 2014NatCo...5E4475Q|arxiv = 1401.5045}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title = Black phosphorus field-effect transistors|journal = Nature Nanotechnology|date = 2014|pages = 372–377|volume = 9|issue = 5|doi = 10.1038/nnano.2014.35|pmid = 24584274|first = Likai|last = Li|first2 = Yijun|last2 = Yu|first3 = Guo Jun|last3 = Ye|first4 = Qingqin|last4 = Ge|first5 = Xuedong|last5 = Ou|first6 = Hua|last6 = Wu|first7 = Donglai|last7 = Feng|first8 = Xian Hui|last8 = Chen|first9 = Yuanbo|last9 = Zhang|bibcode = 2014NatNa...9..372L|arxiv = 1401.4117}}</ref> Phosphorene was initially prepared using mechanical cleavage, a commonly used technique in graphene production that is difficult to scale up. Liquid exfoliation<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|title = Phosphorene: Synthesis, Scale-Up, and Quantitative Optical Spectroscopy|journal = ACS Nano|date = 2015|pages = 8869–8884|volume = 9|issue = 9|doi = 10.1021/acsnano.5b02599|pmid = 26256770|first = Adam H.|last = Woomer|first2 = Tyler W.|last2 = Farnsworth|first3 = Jun|last3 = Hu|first4 = Rebekah A.|last4 = Wells|first5 = Carrie L.|last5 = Donley|first6 = Scott C.|last6 = Warren|arxiv = 1505.04663}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|title = From Black Phosphorus to Phosphorene: Basic Solvent Exfoliation, Evolution of Raman Scattering, and Applications to Ultrafast Photonics|journal = Advanced Functional Materials|pages = 6996–7002|date = 2015|doi = 10.1002/adfm.201502902|first = Zhinan|last = Guo|first2 = Han|last2 = Zhang|first3 = Shunbin|last3 = Lu|first4 = Zhiteng|last4 = Wang|first5 = Siying|last5 = Tang|first6 = Jundong|last6 = Shao|first7 = Zhengbo|last7 = Sun|first8 = Hanhan|last8 = Xie|first9 = Huaiyu|last9 = Wang|volume=25|issue = 45}}</ref> is a promising method for scalable phosphorene production.
[[File:Scotch-tape synthesis of phosphorene.png|thumb|Scotch-tape-based microcleavage synthesis of phosphorene]]
== Synthesis == [[File:Liq exf synthesis of phosphorene.png|thumb|Liquid exfoliation based synthesis of phosphorene]] [[File:Phosphorene structure.png|thumb|Phosphorene structure: (a) tilted view, (b) side view, (c) top view. Red (blue) balls represent phosphorus atoms in the lower (upper) layer.<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1088/1367-2630/16/11/115004| title = Topological origin of quasi-flat edge band in phosphorene| journal = New Journal of Physics| volume = 16| issue = 11| pages = 115004| year = 2014| last1 = Ezawa | first1 = M. | bibcode = 2014NJPh...16k5004E}}</ref>]] Synthesis of phosphorene is a significant challenge. Currently, there are two main ways of phosphorene production: scotch-tape-based microcleavage<ref name=":0" /> and liquid exfoliation,<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" /> while several other methods are being developed as well. Phosphorene production from plasma etching is also reported.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Phosphorene excites materials scientists|url = http://www.nature.com/news/phosphorene-excites-materials-scientists-1.14668|website = Nature News & Comment|date = 4 February 2014|author=Reich, Eugenie Samuel }}</ref>
In scotch-tape-based microcleavage,<ref name=":0" /> phosphorene is mechanically exfoliated from a bulk of black phosphorus crystal using scotch-tape. Phosphorene is then transferred on a Si/SiO<sub>2</sub> substrate, where it is then cleaned with acetone, isopropyl alcohol and methanol to remove any scotch tape residue. The sample is then heated to 180 °C to remove solvent residue.
In the liquid exfoliation method first reported by Brent et al. in 2014<ref name=r1/> and modified by others,<ref name=":1" /> bulk black phosphorus is first ground in a mortar and pestle and then sonicated in deoxygenated, anhydrous organic liquids such as NMP under inert atmosphere using low-power bath sonication. Suspensions are then centrifuged for 30 minutes to filter out the unexfoliated black phosphorus. Resulting 2D monolayer and few-layer phosphorene unoxidized and crystalline structure, while exposure to air oxidizes the phosphorene and produces acid.<ref name=":1" />
Another variation of liquid exfoliation<ref name=":2" /> is “basic N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) liquid exfoliation”. Bulk black phosphorene is added to a saturated NaOH/NMP solution, which is further sonicated for 4 hours to conduct liquid exfoliation. The solution is then centrifuged twice, first for 10 minutes to remove any unexfoliated black phosphorus and then for 20 minutes at higher speed to separate thick layers of phosphorene (5–12 layers) from NMP. The supernatant then is centrifuged again at higher speed for another 20 minutes to separate thinner layers of phosphorene (1–7 layers). The precipitate from centrifugation is then redispersed in water and washed several times by deionized water. Phosphorene/water solution is dropped onto silicon with a 280-nm SiO<sub>2</sub> surface, where it is further dried under vacuum. NMP liquid exfoliation method was shown to yield phosphorene with controllable size and layer number, excellent water stability and in high yield.<ref name=":2" />
The high yield production of phosphorene has been demonstrated by many groups in solvents, but to realize the potential applications of this material, it is crucial to deposit these free-standing nanosheets in solvents systematically on substrates. H. Kaur et al.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1038/srep34095 | pmid = 27671093| pmc = 5037434| title = Large Area Fabrication of Semiconducting Phosphorene by Langmuir-Blodgett Assembly| journal = Sci. Rep.| volume = 6| pages = 34095| year = 2016| last1 = Ritu | first1 = Harneet | bibcode = 2016NatSR...634095K| arxiv = 1605.00875}}</ref> demonstrated the synthesis, interface driven alignment and subsequent functional properties of few layer semiconducting phosphorene using Langmuir-Blodgett assembly. This is the first study which provides a straightforward and versatile solution towards the challenge of assembling nanosheets of phosphorene onto various supports and subsequently use these sheets in an electronic device. Therefore, wet assemblies techniques like Langmuir-Blodgett serves as a very valuable new entry point for the exploration of electronic as well as opto-electronic properties of phosphorene as well as other 2D layered inorganic materials.
It is still a challenge to directly epitaxially grow 2D phosphorene because the stability of black phosphorene is highly sensitive to substrate, which is understanding by theoretical simulations.<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1021/jacs.5b12472 | title = The Critical Role of Substrate in Stabilizing Phosphorene Nanoflake: A Theoretical Exploration| journal = J. Am. Chem. Soc.| volume = 138| issue = 14| pages = 4763–4771| year = 2016| last1 = Gao | first1 = Junfeng | pmid=27022974| arxiv = 1609.05640}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Understanding how flat phosphorus grows|url = http://phys.org/news/2016-09-flat-phosphorus.html|website = Phys.Org.|date = 9 September 2014 }}</ref>
== Properties ==
=== Structure === [[File:Phosphorene TEM2.jpg|thumb|Top-view electron micrograph of phosphorene<ref name="ReferenceA"/>]] Phosphorene [[2D materials]] are composed of individual layers held together by [[van der Waals force]]s in lieu of [[Covalent bond|covalent]] or [[Ionic bonding|ionic]] bonds that are found in most materials. There are five electrons on 3p orbitals of phosphorus atom, thus, giving rise to sp<sup>3</sup> [[Hybridization (chemistry)|hybridization]] of phosphorus atom within phosphorene structure. Monolayered phosphorene exhibits the structure of a quadrangular pyramid because three electrons of P atom bond with three other P atoms covalently at 2.18 Å leaving one lone pair.<ref name=":1" /> Two of the phosphorus atoms are in the plane of the layer at 99° from one another, and the third phosphorus is between the layers at 103°, yielding an average angle of 102°.
According to [[density functional theory]] (DFT) calculations, phosphorene forms in a honeycomb lattice structure with notable nonplanarity in the shape of structural ridges. It is predicted that crystal structure of black phosphorus can be discriminated under high pressure.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Crystal Structures Adopted by Black Phosphorus at High Pressures|journal = Science|date = 29 March 1963|pmid = 17757066|pages = 1291–1292|volume = 139|issue = 3561|doi = 10.1126/science.139.3561.1291|first = John C.|last = Jamieson|bibcode = 1963Sci...139.1291J}}</ref> This is mostly due to the [[Anisotropy|anisotropic]] compressibility of black phosphorus because of the asymmetrical crystal structures. Subsequently, the van der Waals bond can be greatly compressed in the z-direction. However, there is a great variation in compressibility across the orthogonal x-y plane.
It is reported that controlling the centrifugal speed of production may aid in regulating the thickness of a material. For example, centrifuging at 18000 rpm during synthesis produced phosphorene with an average diameter of 210 nm and a thickness of 2.8 ± 1.5 nm (2–7 layers).<ref name=":1" />
=== Band gap and conductivity properties === [[File:Phosphorene AFM.jpg|thumb|[[Atomic force microscopy|AFM]] images of few-layer phosphorene sheets produced by ultrasonic exfoliation of [[black phosphorus]] in [[N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone]] and [[spin coating|spin-coated]] onto a SiO<sub>2</sub>/Si substrate.<ref name=r1>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1039/C4CC05752J| pmid = 25231502| title = Production of few-layer phosphorene by liquid exfoliation of black phosphorus| journal = Chem. Commun.| volume = 50| issue = 87| pages = 13338–13341| year = 2014| last1 = Brent | first1 = J. R. | last2 = Savjani | first2 = N. | last3 = Lewis | first3 = E. A. | last4 = Haigh | first4 = S. J. | last5 = Lewis | first5 = D. J. | last6 = O'Brien | first6 = P. }}</ref>]] Phosphorene has a thickness dependent direct band gap that changes to 1.88 eV in a monolayer from 0.3 eV in the bulk.<ref name=":2" /> Increase in band gap value in single-layer phosphorene is predicted to be caused by the absence of interlayer hybridization near the top of the valence and bottom of the conduction band.<ref name=":0" /> A pronounced peak centered at around 1.45 eV suggests the band gap structure in few- or single-layer phosphorene difference from bulk crystals.<ref name=":0" />
In vacuum or on weak substrate, an interesting reconstruction with nanotubed termination of phosphorene edge is very easy to happen, transforming phosphorene edge from metallic to semiconducting.<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1039/C6NR06201F |url=https://zenodo.org/record/898772| pmid = 27725985| title = Nanotube-Terminated Zigzag Edge of Phosphorene formed by Self-Rolling Reconstruction| journal = Nanoscale| year = 2016| last1 = Gao | first1 = Junfeng | volume=8 | issue = 41| pages=17940–17946|arxiv=1609.05997}}</ref>
=== Air stability=== [[File:Degradation.gif|thumb|AFM of few-layer phosphorene sample continuously taken for 7 days. Phosphorene reacts with oxygen and water to develop liquid phase bubbles.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Toward air-stable multilayer phosphorene thin-films and transistors|journal = Scientific Reports|date = 11 March 2015|pmc = 4355728|pmid = 25758437|volume = 5|doi = 10.1038/srep08989|language = en|first = Joon-Seok|last = Kim|first2 = Yingnan|last2 = Liu|first3 = Weinan|last3 = Zhu|first4 = Seohee|last4 = Kim|first5 = Di|last5 = Wu|first6 = Li|last6 = Tao|first7 = Ananth|last7 = Dodabalapur|first8 = Keji|last8 = Lai|first9 = Deji|last9 = Akinwande|pages=8989|bibcode = 2015NatSR...5E8989K|arxiv = 1412.0355}}</ref>]] One major disadvantage of phosphorene is its air-stability.<ref name=":4">{{cite journal|last1=Kim|first1=Joon-Seok|last2=Liu|first2=Yingnan|last3=Zhu|first3=Weinan|last4=Kim|first4=Seohee|last5=Wu|first5=Di|last6=Tao|first6=Li|last7=Dodabalapur|first7=Ananth|last8=Lai|first8=Keji|last9=Akinwande|first9=Deji|title=Toward air-stable multilayer phosphorene thin-films and transistors|journal=Scientific Reports|date=11 March 2015|volume=5|pages=8989|doi=10.1038/srep08989|pmid=25758437|pmc=4355728|bibcode=2015NatSR...5E8989K|arxiv=1412.0355}}</ref><ref name=":5">{{cite journal|last1=Luo|first1=Xi|last2=Rahbarihagh|first2=Yaghoob|last3=Hwang|first3=James C. M.|last4=Liu|first4=Han|last5=Du|first5=Yuchen|last6=Ye|first6=Peide D.|title=Temporal and Thermal Stability of Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>-Passivated Phosphorene MOSFETs|journal=IEEE Electron Device Letters|date=December 2014|volume=35|issue=12|pages=1314–1316|doi=10.1109/LED.2014.2362841|bibcode=2014IEDL...35.1314L|arxiv=1410.0994}}</ref><ref name=":6">{{cite journal|last1=Wood|first1=Joshua D.|last2=Wells|first2=Spencer A.|last3=Jariwala|first3=Deep|last4=Chen|first4=Kan-Sheng|last5=Cho|first5=EunKyung|last6=Sangwan|first6=Vinod K.|last7=Liu|first7=Xiaolong|last8=Lauhon|first8=Lincoln J.|last9=Marks|first9=Tobin J.|last10=Hersam|first10=Mark C.|title=Effective Passivation of Exfoliated Black Phosphorus Transistors against Ambient Degradation|arxiv=1411.2055|pmid=25380142|journal=Nano Letters|date=10 December 2014|volume=14|issue=12|pages=6964–6970|doi=10.1021/nl5032293|bibcode=2014NanoL..14.6964W}}</ref><ref name=":7">{{cite journal|last1=Koenig|first1=Steven P.|last2=Doganov|first2=Rostislav A.|last3=Schmidt|first3=Hennrik|last4=Castro Neto|first4=A. H.|last5=Özyilmaz|first5=Barbaros|title=Electric field effect in ultrathin black phosphorus|journal=Applied Physics Letters|date=10 March 2014|volume=104|issue=10|pages=103106|doi=10.1063/1.4868132|bibcode=2014ApPhL.104j3106K|arxiv=1402.5718}}</ref><ref name=":8">{{cite journal|last1=Island|first1=Joshua O|last2=Steele|first2=Gary A|last3=Zant|first3=Herre S J van der|last4=Castellanos-Gomez|first4=Andres|title=Environmental instability of few-layer black phosphorus|journal=2D Materials|date=13 January 2015|volume=2|issue=1|pages=011002|doi=10.1088/2053-1583/2/1/011002|bibcode=2015TDM.....2a1002I|arxiv=1410.2608}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Castellanos-Gomez|first1=Andres|last2=Vicarelli|first2=Leonardo|last3=Prada|first3=Elsa|last4=Island|first4=Joshua O|last5=Narasimha-Acharya|first5=K L|last6=Blanter|first6=Sofya I|last7=Groenendijk|first7=Dirk J|last8=Buscema|first8=Michele|last9=Steele|first9=Gary A|last10=Alvarez|first10=J V|last11=Zandbergen|first11=Henny W|last12=Palacios|first12=J J|last13=van der Zant|first13=Herre S J|title=Isolation and characterization of few-layer black phosphorus|journal=2D Materials|date=25 June 2014|volume=1|issue=2|pages=025001|doi=10.1088/2053-1583/1/2/025001|bibcode=2014TDM.....1b5001C|arxiv=1403.0499|hdl=10486/669327}}</ref> Composed of [[Hygroscopy|hygroscopic]] phosphorus and with extremely high [[Surface-area-to-volume ratio|surface-to-volume ratio]], phosphorene reacts with water vapor and oxygen assisted by visible light<ref>{{cite arxiv|last1=Favron|first1=Alexandre|title=Exfoliating pristine black phosphorus down to the monolayer: photo-oxidation and quantum confinement|eprint=1408.0345|display-authors=etal|class=cond-mat.mes-hall|year=2014}}</ref> to degrade within the scope of hours. Through the degradation process, phosphorene (solid) reacts with oxygen/water to develop liquid phase [[acid]] 'bubbles' on the surface, and finally evaporate (vapor) to fully vanish (S-B-V degradation) and severely reducing overall quality.<ref name=":2" />
== Applications ==
=== Transistor === Researchers<ref name=":0" /> have fabricated [[transistor]]s of phosphorene to examine its performance in actual devices. Phosphorene-based transistor consists of a channel of 1.0 μm and uses few layered phosphorene with a thickness varying from 2.1 to over 20 nm. Reduction of the total [[Resistance (electricity)|resistance]] with decreasing gate voltage is observed, indicating the [[P-type semiconductor|p-type]] characteristic of phosphorene. Linear I-V relationship of transistor at low drain bias suggests good contact properties at the phosphorene/metal interface. Good current saturation at high drain bias values was observed.<ref name=":0" /> However, it was seen that the mobility is reduced in few-layer phosphorene when compared to bulk black phosphorus. [[Field-effect mobility]] of phosphorene-based transistor shows a strong thickness dependence, peaking at around 5 nm and decrease steadily with further increase of crystal thickness.
[[Atomic layer deposition|Atomic layer deposition (ALD)]] dielectric layer and/or hydrophobic polymer is used as encapsulation layers in order to prevent device degradation and failure. Phosphorene devices are reported to maintain their function for weeks with encapsulation layer, whereas experience device failure within a week when exposed to ambient condition.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":5" /><ref name=":6" /><ref name=":7" /><ref name=":8" />
=== Inverter === Researchers have also constructed the CMOS [[Power inverter|inverter]] (logic circuit) by combining a phosphorene [[PMOS logic|PMOS]] transistor with a MoS<sub>2</sub> [[NMOS logic|NMOS]] transistor, achieving high heterogeneous integration of semiconducting phosphorene crystals as a new channel material for potential electronic applications.<ref name=":0" /> In the inverter, the power supply voltage is set to be 1 V. The output voltage shows a clear transition from VDD to 0 within the input voltage range from −10 to −2 V. A maximum gain of ~1.4 is attained.
=== Solar-cell donor material (optoelectronics) === The potential applications of mixed bilayer phosphorene in [[Solar cell|solar-cell material]] was examined as well.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|title = Bilayer Phosphorene: Effect of Stacking Order on Bandgap and Its Potential Applications in Thin-Film Solar Cells|journal = The Journal of Physical Chemistry Letters|date = 2014|pages = 1289–1293|volume = 5|issue = 7|doi = 10.1021/jz500409m|pmid = 26274486|first = Jun|last = Dai|first2 = Xiao Cheng|last2 = Zeng|arxiv = 1403.6189}}</ref> The predicted power conversion efficiency for a monolayer MoS<sub>2</sub>/AA-stacked bilayer phosphorene and MoS<sub>2</sub>/AB-stacked bilayer phosphorene can get as high as ~18% and 16%, respectively. Results suggest that trilayer MoS<sub>2</sub> phosphorene is a promising candidate in flexible [[Optoelectronics|optoelectronic devices]].<ref name=":3" />[[File:Bg BP flexible transistor.png|thumb|Illustration of the bottom gated flexible few-layer phosphorene transistors with the hydrophobic dielectric encapsulation.<ref name="Zhu 1883–1890">{{Cite journal|title = Flexible Black Phosphorus Ambipolar Transistors, Circuits and AM Demodulator|journal = Nano Letters|date = 11 March 2015|issn = 1530-6984|pages = 1883–1890|volume = 15|issue = 3|doi = 10.1021/nl5047329|pmid = 25715122|first = Weinan|last = Zhu|first2 = Maruthi N.|last2 = Yogeesh|first3 = Shixuan|last3 = Yang|first4 = Sandra H.|last4 = Aldave|first5 = Joon-Seok|last5 = Kim|first6 = Sushant|last6 = Sonde|first7 = Li|last7 = Tao|first8 = Nanshu|last8 = Lu|first9 = Deji|last9 = Akinwande|bibcode = 2015NanoL..15.1883Z}}</ref>]]
=== Flexible circuits === [[File:20GHz-flexible BP.png|thumb|Electrical characteristic of a flexible black phosphorus transistor showing an intrinsic cutoff frequency of 20 GHz.<ref name="Zhu 2301–2306">{{Cite journal|last=Zhu|first=Weinan|last2=Park|first2=Saungeun|last3=Yogeesh|first3=Maruthi N.|last4=McNicholas|first4=Kyle M.|last5=Bank|first5=Seth R.|last6=Akinwande|first6=Deji|date=13 April 2016|title=Black Phosphorus Flexible Thin Film Transistors at Gighertz Frequencies|journal=Nano Letters|volume=16|issue=4|pages=2301–2306|doi=10.1021/acs.nanolett.5b04768|issn=1530-6984|bibcode=2016NanoL..16.2301Z|pmid=26977902}}</ref>]] Phosphorene is a promising candidate for flexible nano systems due to its ultra-thin nature with ideal electrostatic control and superior mechanical flexibility.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Two-dimensional flexible nanoelectronics|journal = Nature Communications|volume = 5|pages = 5678|doi = 10.1038/ncomms6678|pmid = 25517105|first = Deji|last = Akinwande|first2 = Nicholas|last2 = Petrone|first3 = James|last3 = Hone|year = 2014|bibcode = 2014NatCo...5E5678A}}</ref> Researchers have demonstrated the flexible transistors, circuits and [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Sd6JGbKmvUY AM demodulator] based on few-layer phosphorus, showing enhanced am bipolar transport with high room temperature carrier mobility as high as ~310 cm<sup>2</sup>/Vs and strong current saturation. Fundamental circuit units including digital inverter, voltage amplifier and frequency doubler have been realized.<ref name="Zhu 1883–1890" /> Radio frequency (RF) transistors with highest intrinsic cutoff frequency of 20 GHz has been realized for potential applications in high frequency flexible smart nano systems.<ref name="Zhu 2301–2306"/>
== See also == * [[Borophene]] * [[Germanene]] * [[Graphene]] * [[Silicene]] * [[Stanene]]
